2725DD70DFE70131368968A86D17958E.description: Discuss likes and dislikes of music of different styles.

27257F70DFE70131368868A86D17958E.description: Demonstrate respect for music performed by the student and by other students and professional performers.

27252CF0DFE70131368768A86D17958E.description: Recognize and practice audience or performer behavior appropriate for the context and style of music performed.

2724D7F0DFE70131368668A86D17958E.description: Music Appreciation - The student will learn to appreciate music and expand their listening beyond music currently familiar to the student.

27247D30DFE70131368568A86D17958E.description: Play simple rhythmic patterns using sounds and silences on classroom percussion instruments to accompany songs and rhythm activities.

272419F0DFE70131368468A86D17958E.description: Respond to the beat or rhythm in music by clapping, walking, running, skipping, playing classroom instruments, or chanting.

27239F50DFE70131368368A86D17958E.description: Match pitches, sing in tune and use appropriate tone and expression.

27234500DFE70131368268A86D17958E.description: Participate in music through singing and/or playing instruments.

2722F6D0DFE70131368168A86D17958E.description: Music Expression - The student will perform, imitate, compose a variety of music within specific guidelines.

2722A770DFE70131368068A86D17958E.description: Sing and perform music from a variety of folk, ethnic, patriotic and contemporary songs.

27225110DFE70131367F68A86D17958E.description: Recognize music from our country, work songs, holiday songs and music from different countries.

2721F8A0DFE70131367E68A86D17958E.description: Music History and Culture - The student will recognize the development of music from an historical and cultural perspective.

2721A170DFE70131367D68A86D17958E.description:
Recognize basic features of familiar and unfamiliar songs:
  1. Dynamics - loud and soft
  2. Tempo - fast and slow
  3. Styles - action songs, chants, rhymes, finger plays

272121B0DFE70131367C68A86D17958E.description:
Identify the elements of music:
  1. Melody (up and down)
  2. Harmony (sing with instruments, without instruments)
  3. Tone Color (classroom percussion instruments, sounds from nature, machines, or the environment)
  4. Rhythm (strong and weak beats, steady beat, long and short sounds)
  5. Form (same or different and solo/chorus)
  6. Pitch (high or low)
  7. Tempo (fast or slow)
  8. Dynamics (loud or soft)

2720B990DFE70131367B68A86D17958E.description: Language of Music - The student will read, notate and interpret music.

27201060DFE70131367968A86D17958E.description: Demonstrate thoughtfulness and care in completion of artworks.

271FBD70DFE70131367868A86D17958E.description: Demonstrate respect for student work and the work of others.

271F5200DFE70131367768A86D17958E.description: Demonstrate appropriate behavior while viewing art.

271EF240DFE70131367668A86D17958E.description: Visual Art Appreciation - The student will appreciate visual art as a vehicle of human expression.

271E7E30DFE70131367568A86D17958E.description: Use art media and tools in a safe and responsible manner.

271E19D0DFE70131367468A86D17958E.description: Use objects to express creative ideas.

271DC9B0DFE70131367368A86D17958E.description:
Manipulate a variety of materials (media).
  1. Drawing Media: markers, chalks, crayons
  2. Painting Media: finger paint
  3. Sculpture Media: clay, string, paper, foil, cardboard, found objects
  4. Mixed Media: tissue, photos, found objects, foil, fiber, paint, paper

271D7820DFE70131367268A86D17958E.description: Visual Art Expression - The student will observe, select, and utilize a variety of ideas and subject matter in creating original works of visual art.

271D2170DFE70131367168A86D17958E.description: Discuss and identify art used every day in the home, community or school (e.g. signs, posters, cartoons, labels, menus)

271CBBB0DFE70131367068A86D17958E.description: Identify other art forms such as music, dance, and drama.

271C6D30DFE70131366F68A86D17958E.description: Visual Art History and Culture - The student will recognize the development of visual art from a historical and cultural perspective.

271C1DE0DFE70131366E68A86D17958E.description: Explore different art methods such as drawing, painting, weaving, and sculpting.

271BC5C0DFE70131366D68A86D17958E.description: Name and describe elements of art: line, color, form, shape, texture, value and space.

271B61E0DFE70131366C68A86D17958E.description: Language of Visual Art - The student will identify visual art terms.

comments: The Arts provide children with many opportunities for self-expression. Art, music, and dramatic play centers expose children to dance, music (singing, use of instruments), visual art (drawing, sculpting, painting), and drama and help them develop an appreciation of both individual and group expression.

271A6AC0DFE70131366968A86D17958E.description: The student will explore various careers and the concept of employment (e.g., school personnel, community helpers).

2719C8A0DFE70131366768A86D17958E.description: Recognize money is used to purchase goods.

27196A80DFE70131366668A86D17958E.description: The student will identify basic economic concepts.

2718CA60DFE70131366468A86D17958E.description: Explore through literature the people and events honored in commemorative holidays (e.g., Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, Presidents' Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Thanksgiving).

271879B0DFE70131366368A86D17958E.description: Explore through literature examples of past events and important Americans in legends and historical accounts (e.g., Paul Revere's ride, Johnny Appleseed, Betsy Ross).

271826B0DFE70131366268A86D17958E.description: The student will understand that history relates to events and people of other times and places.

27176710DFE70131366068A86D17958E.description: Explore how children within the local community and around the world are unique as to languages, food, clothing, transportation, and customs.

271705A0DFE70131365F68A86D17958E.description: Explore how children within the local community and around the world have needs in common (e.g., food, clothing, shelter).

2716AA80DFE70131365E68A86D17958E.description: The student will discuss how children in various communities and cultures are alike and different.

27165940DFE70131365D68A86D17958E.description: Recognize Oklahoma on a map of the United States.

2715EFB0DFE70131365C68A86D17958E.description: Identify a map as a drawing of a particular location.

27156340DFE70131365B68A86D17958E.description: Begin to develop an understanding of city/town, state, and country.

2714FBA0DFE70131365A68A86D17958E.description: Locate and describe familiar places (e.g., classroom, home, school).

2714A700DFE70131365968A86D17958E.description: The student will demonstrate knowledge of basic geographic concepts.

27140300DFE70131365768A86D17958E.description: Describe the importance of individual responsibility (e.g., responsibility as a student, family member, citizen).

2713A780DFE70131365668A86D17958E.description: The student will explain the importance of individual responsibility.

271358E0DFE70131365568A86D17958E.description: Identify the Oklahoma flag as a symbol of our state.

27130790DFE70131365468A86D17958E.description: Identify the American flag as a national symbol of our country and understand the etiquette of its use.

2712B0A0DFE70131365368A86D17958E.description: The student will recognize patriotic symbols and activities.

27124E00DFE70131365268A86D17958E.description: Show respect for others and their property.

2711E950DFE70131365168A86D17958E.description: Listen to others while in large and small groups.

27118AD0DFE70131365068A86D17958E.description: Exhibit behavior that demonstrates an understanding of school and classroom guidelines (e.g., rules, routines, schedules, procedures).

27113800DFE70131364F68A86D17958E.description: Work and play cooperatively in a variety of settings (e.g., in large and small groups, learning centers).

2710E7D0DFE70131364E68A86D17958E.description: The student will exhibit traits of good citizenship.

comments: Social studies provides an opportunity to develop an integrated curriculum using civics, geography, history and economics. Learning experiences may be provided through learning centers, resource people, projects, and field trips.

270FD6D0DFE70131364B68A86D17958E.description: State his/her full name, age, birthdate, address, telephone number, and name of parent or guardian.

270F8760DFE70131364A68A86D17958E.description: Attend to personal tasks (e.g., dressing self, washing hands).

270F2DD0DFE70131364968A86D17958E.description: Recognize potential safety hazards and take action to protect self (e.g., bicycle, water, fire, vehicle, firearm, bus, playground, pedestrian).

270EDA30DFE70131364868A86D17958E.description: The student will participate in activities to develop the skills necessary for caring for oneself

270E85B0DFE70131364768A86D17958E.description: Stay involved in a self-selected activity for approximately 15 to 20 minutes.

270E35D0DFE70131364668A86D17958E.description: Select and complete a task while working at a learning center.

270DE010DFE70131364568A86D17958E.description: Choose a variety of materials and activities from learning centers.

270D88F0DFE70131364468A86D17958E.description: Work independently and/or cooperatively to solve problems.

270D26A0DFE70131364368A86D17958E.description: The student will participate in activities to develop the skills necessary for work and interacting with others.

comments: Social skills include interacting with others, work habits and self-help skills. To develop these skills, children need daily opportunities to choose activities and materials.

270C6670DFE70131364168A86D17958E.description: Observes and describes characteristics of shadows (e.g., shadows at different times of day).

270C14B0DFE70131364068A86D17958E.description: Describes simple conservation measures used to protect the environment (e.g., recycling, careful use of water).

270BC370DFE70131363F68A86D17958E.description: Observes and describes characteristics of the four seasons (e.g., temperature, weather, appropriate clothing, changing leaves).

270B6DF0DFE70131363E68A86D17958E.description: Observes and describes daily weather (e.g., sunny, cloudy, rainy, snowy, windy, hot, warm, cold).

270B0A20DFE70131363D68A86D17958E.description: Explores and describes the properties of common earth materials (e.g., soil, rocks, water).

270AB200DFE70131363C68A86D17958E.description: The student will investigate and observe the basic concepts of the Earth and sky.

270A0B00DFE70131363A68A86D17958E.description: Observes and describes how animals move (e.g., walk, crawl, hop, fly).

2709B460DFE70131363968A86D17958E.description: Observes and describes the changes that plants and animals go through during their life (e.g., seed/plant, egg/chicken).

27095C50DFE70131363868A86D17958E.description: Observes and describes what various plants and animals need for growth.

27090960DFE70131363768A86D17958E.description: The student will observe and investigate plants and animals.

270861C0DFE70131363568A86D17958E.description: Observes and describes how objects move (e.g., slide, turn, twirl, roll).

2707FB20DFE70131363468A86D17958E.description: Compares and describes the properties of some objects (e.g., magnetic-nonmagnetic, float-sink, heavy-light, rough-smooth, hard-soft, solid-liquid, wet-dry.

27078850DFE70131363368A86D17958E.description: Observes, describes, sorts, and classifies the sensory attributes of objects according to taste, smell, hearing, touch, and light.

27073240DFE70131363268A86D17958E.description: The student will investigate and describe objects that can be sorted in terms of physical properties.

27069150DFE70131363068A86D17958E.description: Explores cause and effect (e.g., temperature determines clothing choices).

270639C0DFE70131362F68A86D17958E.description: Selects and describes simple science tools (e.g., simple magnet, magnifying glass, thermometer).

2705DFD0DFE70131362E68A86D17958E.description: Asks questions, make predictions, and communicate observations orally and/or in drawings.

27058B90DFE70131362D68A86D17958E.description: Participates in simple experiments to discover information (e.g., bottles of water or homemade telephone to learn about vibration and sound, simple scale to determine heavy and light).

270530F0DFE70131362C68A86D17958E.description: Observes, describes, sorts, and classifies objects according to their common properties (e.g., animals, plants, shells, rocks, buttons).

2704D940DFE70131362B68A86D17958E.description: The student will investigate and experiment with objects to discover information.

comments: Science knowledge is developed through experiences with real animals, plants and objects in the classroom and the environment.

2703D860DFE70131362868A86D17958E.description: Discuss basic health needs of human beings (e.g., dental, hearing and vision care, exercise, nutrition).

27038660DFE70131362768A86D17958E.description: Experience sustained moderate physical activity for short periods of time.

270331F0DFE70131362668A86D17958E.description: Associate physical activity with the benefit of maintaining fitness and personal well-being.

2702CD40DFE70131362568A86D17958E.description: The student will participate in health-enhancing activities for the development of lifetime health and fitness.

27021190DFE70131362368A86D17958E.description: Hold and use pencils, crayons, and markers using thumb and two fingers.

2701C0D0DFE70131362268A86D17958E.description: Demonstrate increased control of hand and eye coordination while using pegs, beads, pattern blocks, crayons, pencils, paint brushes, fingerpaint, scissors, glue, and a variety of puzzles.

27016F20DFE70131362168A86D17958E.description: The student will participate in activities that involve small motor skills.

2700BA10DFE70131361F68A86D17958E.description: Coordinate large arm movements (e.g., easel painting, woodworking, climbing, throwing, playing rhythm band instruments, writing on chalkboard, playing with blocks, catching, and tossing).

270064F0DFE70131361E68A86D17958E.description: Walk and balance on a four-inch line or balance beam.

27000200DFE70131361D68A86D17958E.description: Balance on one foot for approximately five seconds.

26FF0880DFE70131361B68A86D17958E.description: Combine various movement patterns to music, but not necessarily in time.

26FEA960DFE70131361A68A86D17958E.description: Demonstrate nonlocomotor movements (e.g., bending, pulling, pushing, stretching, swaying, swinging, turning, twisting).

26FE5780DFE70131361968A86D17958E.description: Demonstrate basic locomotor movements (e.g., galloping, hopping, jumping, running, skipping, sliding).

26FE0810DFE70131361868A86D17958E.description: The student will participate in activities that involve large motor skills.

26FD6370DFE70131361668A86D17958E.description: Motor Skill and Lifetime Activity Development
comments: Young children need the opportunity to develop large and small motor skills through indoor and outdoor activities and games for the benefit of personal fitness and well-being.

26FD12F0DFE70131361568A86D17958E.description: Create and verbally explain a data display or graph (e.g., real object graph, pictorial graphs).

26FCC3E0DFE70131361468A86D17958E.description: Collects and analyze information about objects and events in the environment.

26FC7470DFE70131361368A86D17958E.description: Describes similarities and differences between objects.

26FC2340DFE70131361268A86D17958E.description: Develops abilities to collect, describe, and record information through a variety of means including discussion, drawings, maps, charts, and graphs.

26FBC970DFE70131361168A86D17958E.description: Use numbers and counting as a means for solving problems and measuring quantity.

26FB0040DFE70131360F68A86D17958E.description: Data Analysis - The student will collect and display data in a group setting.

26FAA410DFE70131360E68A86D17958E.description: Money. Identify the coins penny, nickel, dime, and quarter.

26FA5390DFE70131360D68A86D17958E.description: Identify the days of the week and months of the year.

26F9F990DFE70131360C68A86D17958E.description: Tell time on digital and analog clocks to the hour.

26F90F60DFE70131360A68A86D17958E.description: Identify the appropriate instrument used to measure length (ruler), weight (scale), time (clock: digital and analog; calendar: day, month, year, season), and temperature (thermometer).

26F8BD00DFE70131360968A86D17958E.description: Compare and order objects in graduated order (e.g., shortest to tallest, thinnest to thickest).

26F868B0DFE70131360868A86D17958E.description: Compare objects according to observable attributes (e.g., long, longer, longest; short, shorter, shortest; big, bigger, biggest; small, smaller, smallest; small, medium, large).

26F81300DFE70131360768A86D17958E.description: Measure objects using nonstandard units of measurement (e.g., pencil, paper clip, block).

26F75640DFE70131360568A86D17958E.description: Measurement - The student will explore the concepts of nonstandard and standard measurement.

26F70160DFE70131360468A86D17958E.description: Model and use words indicating relative position or direction (e.g., students describe the relationships between self and objects in space using on, above, below, beside, under, on top of, behind, and over).

26F69DB0DFE70131360368A86D17958E.description: Identify, name, and describe a variety of three-dimensional geometric shapes such as spheres, cubes, and cylinders.

26F63BE0DFE70131360268A86D17958E.description: Identify, name, and describe a variety of basic two-dimensional geometric shapes such as squares, triangles, circles, rectangles, (regular) hexagons, and (isosceles) trapezoids presented in a variety of ways (e.g. with different sizes of orientation).

26F5D450DFE70131360168A86D17958E.description: Geometry - The student will identify common geometric shapes and explore the relationship of objects in the environment.

26F57710DFE70131360068A86D17958E.description: Combine and remove objects from sets and verbally describe the result (e.g., adding objects to a set makes the set larger, subtracting objects from a set makes the set smaller.

26F525B0DFE7013135FF68A86D17958E.description: Identify and use ordinal numbers to order objects first through tenth.

26F4D3E0DFE7013135FE68A86D17958E.description: Identify and write numerals zero through twenty, in and out of sequence. Children may still be reversing some numerals.

26F47860DFE7013135FD68A86D17958E.description: Identify and create sets of objects zero through twenty.

26F40C90DFE7013135FC68A86D17958E.description: Count objects in a set one-by-one from one through twenty.

26F38E80DFE7013135FB68A86D17958E.description: Count forward to twenty and backward from ten.

26F33B80DFE7013135FA68A86D17958E.description: Pair and count objects using one-to-one correspondence (e.g., one napkin for each child at snack time).

26F2E580DFE7013135F968A86D17958E.description: Compare a group or set to another group, set, or numerical quantity and verbally explain which has more, less, or equivalent quantities.

26F28A00DFE7013135F868A86D17958E.description: Number Sense - The student will understand the relationship between numbers and quantities.

26F23810DFE7013135F768A86D17958E.description: Use object to demonstrate "related facts" such as 3 + 4 = 7: 7 - 4 = 3.

26F1E400DFE7013135F668A86D17958E.description: Explain verbally and extend simple patterns (e.g., )

26F18DA0DFE7013135F568A86D17958E.description: Sort and group objects into a set and explain verbally what the objects have in common (e.g., color, size, shape).

26F13280DFE7013135F468A86D17958E.description: Algebraic Reasoning: Patterns - The student will sort and classify objects and analyze simple patterns.

comments: Young children begin to develop mathematical understanding through experiences with a wide variety of real objects provided in learning centers and practical situations (e.g., blocks, pegs, buttons, cooking).

26F04430DFE7013135F268A86D17958E.description: Respond to visual messages by distinguishing between reality and fantasy in stories, videos and television programs.

26EFF400DFE7013135F168A86D17958E.description: Interpret Meaning - The student will interpret and evaluate various ways visual image-makers including graphic artists, illustrators, and news photographers represent meaning.

26EF9F20DFE7013135F068A86D17958E.description: Visual Literacy: The student will interpret, evaluate, and compose visual messages.

26EF3240DFE7013135EF68A86D17958E.description: Show respect and consideration for others in physical communications.

26EEDC20DFE7013135EE68A86D17958E.description: Show respect and consideration for others in verbal communications.

26EE8560DFE7013135ED68A86D17958E.description: Group Interaction - The student will use effective communication strategies in pair and small group context.

26EE1350DFE7013135EC68A86D17958E.description: Recite short poems, rhymes and songs.

26EDA5F0DFE7013135EB68A86D17958E.description: Share information and ideas speaking in clear, complete, coherent sentences.

26ED4600DFE7013135EA68A86D17958E.description: Speaking - The student will express ideas or opinions in group or individual settings.

26EC94D0DFE7013135E868A86D17958E.description: Listen with interest to stories read aloud.
comments: Example: Trade books and shared reading.

26EC40B0DFE7013135E768A86D17958E.description: Hear and repeat sounds in a sequence.
comments: Example: Hand rhythms, vocal sounds, numbers in a sequence, letters in a sequence, five sounds in a sequence

26EBE230DFE7013135E668A86D17958E.description: Listening - The student will listen for information and for pleasure.

26EB7900DFE7013135E568A86D17958E.description: Oral Language/Listening and Speaking: The student will demonstrate thinking skills in listening and speaking.

26EB1130DFE7013135E468A86D17958E.description: Print his/her first and last name.

26EAC180DFE7013135E368A86D17958E.description: Trace, copy and generate letters although children may still be reversing some letters.

26EA7280DFE7013135E268A86D17958E.description: Begin printing legibly using correct spacing between letters and words.

26EA1F80DFE7013135E168A86D17958E.description: Begin using upper and lower case letters.

26E9C060DFE7013135E068A86D17958E.description: Print using left to right progression moving from the top to the bottom of the page

26E96670DFE7013135DF68A86D17958E.description: Handwriting: Demonstrate appropriate handwriting in the writing process.

26E91310DFE7013135DE68A86D17958E.description: Generates inventive spelling representing initial and ending sounds.

26E8BC80DFE7013135DD68A86D17958E.description: Understand and record some beginning and ending sounds in words.

26E84960DFE7013135DC68A86D17958E.description: Understand that letters have different sounds.

26E7E6F0DFE7013135DB68A86D17958E.description: Spelling: Demonstrate the process of representing language by means of a writing system.

26E793A0DFE7013135DA68A86D17958E.description: Sentence Structure: Demonstrate, with teacher assistance, appropriate sentence structure in writing a complete sentence.

26E74500DFE7013135D968A86D17958E.description: Punctuation: Begin to use correct terminal (ending) punctuation.

26E6A3E0DFE7013135D768A86D17958E.description: Capitalize the first word of a sentence.

26E64930DFE7013135D668A86D17958E.description: Mechanics: Demonstrate appropriate language mechanics in writing.

26E5F940DFE7013135D568A86D17958E.description: Grammar/Usage: Begin to recognize appropriate use of nouns, verbs, and adjectives.

26E5A940DFE7013135D468A86D17958E.description: Grammar/Usage and Mechanics - The student will demonstrate appropriate practices in writing by applying Standard English conventions.

26E55960DFE7013135D368A86D17958E.description: Construct journal entries using illustrations and beginning writing skills.

26E50530DFE7013135D268A86D17958E.description: Introduce modes and forms of stories with a consistent focus of a beginning, middle, and end that describe, explain, or tell about familiar objects, people, places, events, or experiences.

26E4A2E0DFE7013135D168A86D17958E.description: Modes and Forms of Writing. The student will communicate through a variety of written forms, for various purposes, and to a specific audience or person.

26E44610DFE7013135D068A86D17958E.description: Presents his or her own writing which may include pictures, attempts at letters, initial consonants, words, or phrases to the group, teacher and/or parent.

26E3E9E0DFE7013135CF68A86D17958E.description: Dictate a story about an exciting event or experience.

26E38F90DFE7013135CE68A86D17958E.description: Participate in frequent writing opportunities including modeled writing, shared writing, journal writing, and interactive writing.

26E338C0DFE7013135CD68A86D17958E.description: Writing Process - The student will use the writing process to write coherently.

26E2C0F0DFE7013135CC68A86D17958E.description: Writing/Grammar/Usage and Mechanics: The student will express ideas effectively in written modes for a variety of purposes and audiences.

26E25FA0DFE7013135CB68A86D17958E.description: Begin to identify the appropriate source needed to gather information (e.g., fiction book, nonfiction book, newspaper, map, resource person)

26E20F80DFE7013135CA68A86D17958E.description: Accessing Information - The student will select the best source for a given purpose.

26E1BFB0DFE7013135C968A86D17958E.description: Research and Information - The student will conduct research and organize information.

comments: Example: Read The Mitten by Jan Brett and tell what happened to the mitten because of the animals.

26E111C0DFE7013135C768A86D17958E.description: Summarize main points and events of a simple story.

26E0C110DFE7013135C668A86D17958E.description: Place events in sequential order by telling the beginning, middle and ending.
comments: Example: Read and retell a story orally or by illustrating the beginning, middle and ending.

Example: Listen to Tops and Bottoms. This is a fiction book about a hare and a bear's adventure to determine who gets the tops and who gets the bottoms of their vegetables. Read Eating the Alphabet by Lois Ehlert which is a nonfiction book and discuss the differences in books.

26DF60B0DFE7013135C268A86D17958E.description: Literature - The student will read to construct meaning and respond to a wide variety of literary forms.

26DF0130DFE7013135C168A86D17958E.description: Tell what is happening in a picture.

26DEA080DFE7013135C068A86D17958E.description: Make predictions and confirm after reading or listening to text.

26DE4AB0DFE7013135BF68A86D17958E.description: Retell, reenact or dramatize a story read to the student or by the student.

26DDF0E0DFE7013135BE68A86D17958E.description: Use prereading skills (e.g., connecting prior knowledge to text, making predictions about text and using picture clues).

26DD9D30DFE7013135BD68A86D17958E.description: Comprehension - The student will associate meaning and understanding with reading.

26DD3D60DFE7013135BC68A86D17958E.description: Recognize some common words by sight, including but not limited to "a," "the," "I," "you," "my," "I," "are."

26DCB8B0DFE7013135BB68A86D17958E.description: "Read" familiar texts emergently, not necessarily verbatim from the print alone.

26DC5F00DFE7013135BA68A86D17958E.description: Fluency - The student will demonstrate the ability to identify words in text.

26DC0070DFE7013135B968A86D17958E.description: Use new vocabulary and language in own speech and writing.

26DBB0B0DFE7013135B868A86D17958E.description: Increase personal vocabulary by listening to a variety of text and literature.

26DB5FC0DFE7013135B768A86D17958E.description: Vocabulary - The student will develop and expand knowledge of words and word meanings to increase their vocabulary.

26DA57A0DFE7013135B468A86D17958E.description: Phonics/Decoding - The student will demonstrate the ability to apply sound-symbol relationships.

comments: Example: bat = /b/ /a/ /t/
26D9F8F0DFE7013135B368A86D17958E.description: Begin to segment phonemes of one syllable words.

26D99790DFE7013135B268A86D17958E.description: Begin to blend phonemes to form a word.
comments: Example: /b/ /a/ /t/ = bat

26D94040DFE7013135B168A86D17958E.description: Recognize the same sounds in different words.
comments: Example: /b/ in ball, big, and bun
Example: /p/ in tap, rip, and mop
Example: /t/ in bat
26D8EA00DFE7013135B068A86D17958E.description: Recognize ending sounds in spoken words.

26D887D0DFE7013135AF68A86D17958E.description: Distinguish onset (beginning sound(s)) and rimes in one-syllable words.
comments: Example: Onset - /b/ in bat
Example: Rime – at in bat

26D82D10DFE7013135AE68A86D17958E.description: Identify and count syllables in spoken words.

26D77F40DFE7013135AD68A86D17958E.description: Identify and produce simple rhyming pairs.
comments: Example: bat/cat

26D71710DFE7013135AC68A86D17958E.description: Phonological/Phonemic Awareness - The student will demonstrate the ability to hear, identify, and manipulate large parts of spoken language (e.g., words, syllables, onsets, and rimes) and individual sounds (phonemes) in spoken words.

26D6C7E0DFE7013135AB68A86D17958E.description: Recognize and name all capital and lowercase letters of the alphabet.

26D62DA0DFE7013135A968A86D17958E.description: Recognize that sentences in print are made up of separate words.

26D5DD40DFE7013135A868A86D17958E.description: Understand that printed materials provide information.

26D586C0DFE7013135A768A86D17958E.description: Follow words from left to right and from top to bottom on the printed page.

26D529D0DFE7013135A668A86D17958E.description: Identify the front cover, back cover, title page of a book and title and author.

26D4D3B0DFE7013135A568A86D17958E.description: Demonstrate correct book orientation by holding book correctly (right side up) and indicating where to begin (e.g., front to back, top to bottom, left to right).

26D47FA0DFE7013135A468A86D17958E.description: Print Awareness - The student will understand the characteristics of written language.

26D42110DFE7013135A368A86D17958E.description: Reading/Literature: The student will apply a wide range of strategies to comprehend, interpret, evaluate, appreciate and respond to a wide variety of text and literature.

comments: Young children begin to develop language arts skills through the context of shared reading with quality children's literature, shared writing, language experience, reading and writing centers.

26D35B10DFE7013135A168A86D17958E.description: Think of new uses for familiar materials.

26D30040DFE7013135A068A86D17958E.description: Develop and verbalize solutions to simple problems.

26D2A360DFE70131359F68A86D17958E.description: Express thoughts and ideas about work and play.

26D24F70DFE70131359E68A86D17958E.description: The student will be encouraged to participate in activities that foster individual creativity.

comments: Creative skills are developed by engaging children in activities with play dough, sand, water, dramatic play, blocks, creative stories, art, music, movement, and a variety of other materials.
